senses.de: Money that you owe to someone
senses.ex: She is trying to pay off a large debt.

Tips.title: Financial Context
Tips.description: Use 'debt' to talk about money borrowed that must be paid back, often with interest.
Tips.example: Her car loan added to her growing debt.

Tips.title: Metaphoric Use
Tips.description: 'In debt' is often used metaphorically to describe feeling obligated to someone for their help.
Tips.example: He's been in debt to his friend ever since that favor.

Tips.title: Common Collocations
Tips.description: Commonly paired phrases include 'debt relief,' 'debt consolidation,' and 'debt management.'
Tips.example: Many seek debt relief to escape financial pressure.

senses.de: An obligation or duty to repay or do something in return for something received
senses.ex: I feel a deep debt of gratitude towards my teachers.

Tips.title: Gratitude Expression
Tips.description: Use 'debt of gratitude' to express a strong feeling of thanks for something someone has done.
Tips.example: We owe the volunteers a debt of gratitude for their time.

Tips.title: Honor Bound
Tips.description: 'Debt of honour' implies a moral obligation that's not legally binding, often in a formal context.
Tips.example: He repaid his mentor through a debt of honour.

Tips.title: Emotional Debt
Tips.description: Talking about an 'emotional debt' can describe feelings of owing someone for personal support.
Tips.example: She felt an emotional debt to her aunt who raised her.

senses.ex: The country's public debt has risen dramatically.

Tips.title: Economic Term
Tips.description: 'Debt' is used to describe the total amount of money a country owes to its creditors.
Tips.example: The national debt is often debated in politics.

Tips.title: Public vs. Private
Tips.description: 'Public debt' refers to government debt, while 'private debt' is owed by individuals or businesses.
Tips.example: Public debt affects a country's economy differently than private debt.

Tips.title: Borrowing Limit
Tips.description: A 'debt ceiling' is the maximum amount of debt a government allows itself to hold.
Tips.example: Congress debated raising the debt ceiling.

Deficit.wordDefinition:
Debt and deficit are both terms related to money owed by a person or a country.

Deficit refers to the difference between the amount of money a government or organization spends and the amount of money it earns.

If the amount spent is greater than the amount earned, then the result is a deficit. This means that the government or organization is spending more than it can afford and may need to borrow money to cover the difference.

To summarize, debt is the total amount of money owed by a person or country, while deficit is the difference between spending and earnings.

Debt is applicable when referring to the total borrowing of an entity, while deficit is applicable when referring to the excess spending of an entity.

Liability.wordDefinition:
Liability refers to a broader category of financial obligations.

It can include debts, but it can also include other things like legal obligations or contractual commitments. For example, a company may have a liability to pay employee salaries or a liability to provide certain services to customers.

Debt is a specific type of liability that refers to money owed, while liability is a broader term that encompasses broader financial obligations.

Mortgage.wordDefinition:
A mortgage is a specific type of debt that you take on to buy a house. It's money that you borrow from a bank or a lender to pay for the house, and you have to pay it back over many years.

So, in short, debt is a general term for money that you owe, while a mortgage is a specific type of debt that you take on to buy a house.

Obligation.wordDefinition:
Debt refers to something you owe to someone, mostly money that you need to pay back. Obligation refers to a sense of duty or responsibility towards something or someone.

Debt is applicable when you borrow money and need to pay it back, while obligation is applicable when you have a sense of duty towards something or someone, even if it does not involve money.

For example, you may have an obligation to take care of a younger sibling or to study hard for exams.

videos.Text: Interest rates, meanwhile, reflect the cost of taking on debt for individuals and companies. The rate is typically an annual percentage of a loan that borrowers pay to their creditors until the loan is repaid. Low interest rates mean that companies can afford to borrow more money, which they can use to invest in more projects.
